DOC.HEAD: North Korean Missile Help Sought by Syria, Egypt
DOC.TEXT: Syria is believed to be seeking North Korea's help in acquiring new surface-to-surface missiles after the United States pressured China to cancel a reported deal, Israeli military sources said Friday. The sources also said North Korea and Egypt have begun a project to develop missiles patterned after Soviet-designed Scud missiles. The revelation by the sources, who spoke on condition of anonymity, comes at a time of mounting concern in Israel about an intensified missile race in the Middle East. Fears intensified following Iraq's Dec. 7 launching of the Abed, a 48-ton, three-stage ballistic missile that Baghdad claimed was capable of putting satellites into space. North Korea has a well-developed arms industry, and the Israeli sources said it had supplied Iran with Soviet-designed Scud surface-to-surface missiles during Tehran's war with Iraq. The military sources said part of the Egyptian-North Korean missile project was being developed in Egypt. Aharon Levran, a retired brigadier general and an independent military analyst, said Egypt had an arsenal of aging Scud missiles provided by the Soviet Union and had apparently turned to North Korea last year for help in modernizing them. ``It's not known exactly what sort of help the North Koreans can provide, whether it is just to renew the old Soviet missiles and provide spare parts or maybe install improved components such as guidance,'' he said. He also said published reports indicated North Korea was helping Iran develop its own surface-to-surface missile and was training pilots for the Tehran regime. The Scud-B, which has a range of 180 miles and poor accuracy, was introduced into the Middle East in the early 1970s. Cairo apparently dropped out of a project with Argentina and Iraq t develop a more accurate missile called the Condor 2 or Badr 2000. The missile was intended to have a range of about 540 miles and better accuracy than the Scud. Egypt's withdrawal followed political pressure brought by Washington after the arrest of two Egyptian colonels who were accused of trying to smuggle technology out of the United States that could be used to improve missile accuracy. President Bush sent National Security Adviser Brent Scowcroft to Beijing this month to urge the Chinese to cancel a planned sale to Syria of M-9 surface-to-surface missiles, which have a range of 370 miles and would be capable of hitting targets deep inside Israel. The Jerusalem Post reported Syria signed an agreement with China for 140 M-9 missiles at a cost of $170 million. Israeli officials have said Israel was informed that China had pledged to refrain from such sales, although some doubts still existed about whether China would go through with the sale. Officials in Beijing have denied any sale was in the works. Syria has Soviet SS-21 missiles capable of hitting northern Israel and Scud-B missiles. Levran said the Syrians would likely be interested in North Korean help only if they could improve the range and accuracy of the Scuds. Unlike the Egyptians, he noted, Syria has close ties with the Soviet Union and would likely be able to get replacement missiles without the need for renovation.
